description: From New Latin factotum (literally “do everything”), from Latin fac, present singular imperative of faciō (“do, make”) + tōtum (“everything”); attested in English from 1566.

entries.meaning: (dated) A person having many diverse activities or responsibilities.
An individual employed to do all sorts of duties.
examples: 2021 November 5,  Schwarz, Jon,  The Intercept‎[1], First Look Media:Biden’s and Bush’s factotums had to walk their statements quickly back, emphasizing that U.S. policy had not changed.
Synonyms: handyman, jack of all trades, sciolist

entries.meaning: (printing, historical) A large decorative printing block with a central space into which any letter can be inserted, used to mark the beginning of a chapter of a book in early printing.
